mixed-citation.article-title: Taxonomic review of the Dichotomius (Luederwaldtinia) agenor species group (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Scarabaeinae)

tp:treatment-sec.p: Fig. 3 , Map 1

Pinotus agenor Harold, 1869: 141
(original description).

Pinotus agenor
–
Luederwaldt 1929: 99
. —
Blackwelder 1944: 69
.

Dichotomius agenor
–
Howden & Young 1981: 13
. —
Medina et al. 2001: 138
. —
Ratcliffe 2002: 15
— Sarmiento & Amat 2014: 89–90.
Diagnosis

Dichotomius agenor
is separated from the other species in the group by the following combination of characters: large male fronto-clypeal carina with lower part wider than high, with median tubercle bifurcate apically, concave between central and lateral tubercles. Pronotum with pronounced, truncate anterior declivity, when viewed laterally. External margin of hypomeron bearing multiple rows of disorganized long setae, all approximately the same length, that can be seen in dorsal view. Posterior edge of metacoxa bearing two rows of disorganized ocellate punctures, separated by half the diameter of a puncture.

Redescription
Male
MEASUREMENTS. Length: 20.5 mm .

Fig. 3.
Dichotomius agenor ( Harold, 1869 )
. A–B . Dorsal habitus. A . ♂. B . ♀. C . Posterior view of the cephalic carina, concavity between the central and the lateral tubercles, apically emarginate. D . Lateral view of the pronotum, anterior declivity truncate. E . Ventral view of the metacoxa, displaying two rows of punctures on the posterior margin. F . Lateral view of the aedeagus. G . Ventral view of the aedeagus. H–I . Lamella copulatrix.
PARAMERES AND LAMELLA COPULATRIX OF AEDEAGUS. As in Fig. 3 F–H.
Morphological variation
Females ( Fig. 3B )
As males except for the following characters:
PRONOTUM. Weak medial knob, only detectable in lateral view. Hypomeron setae longer and denser than in males.
Remarks

Luederwaldt (1929) placed this species in the
assifer
section which included species from the
assifer
and
agenor
groups. Harold’s type material was from Colombia , but the label does not specify the exact locality. This species is known to occur in Panama , Colombia and Venezuela from 100 to 1500 m a.s.l., in the Caribbean subregion as proposed by Morrone (2001) . It is found in the Magdalena and Maracaibo Provinces, associated with dry and humid forests ( Morrone 2001 ). Individuals of this species are easily confused with
D. enioi
sp. nov. , a Central American species.
